column8: A Hidden Gem of Ancient Art
column11: Thivanka Image House was one of the highlights of my visit to Polonnaruwa and feels like a true hidden gem. Many people skip it, but it’s absolutely worth seeing if you love history and art. Inside the building, you’ll find a huge standing Buddha statue that’s incredibly impressive. But what really amazed me were the ancient wall paintings still visible in parts of the interior. Even though some of the paint has faded over the centuries, you can still see beautiful details and colors that have survived for over 800 years. It’s incredible how talented the artists were back then. The atmosphere inside feels peaceful and a bit mysterious, as if you’re stepping back into another time. It’s not as crowded as other sites, which makes it even more special to explore. Tip: You can’t wear shoes inside, so bring a pair of socks, especially if you visit during the heat of the day because the stones can get warm! If you’re visiting Polonnaruwa, don’t miss Thivanka Image House. It’s perfect for anyone who loves hidden places, ancient art, and discovering the best places to travel.

This is one of my favourite parts of the ruins at Polonnaruwa Ancient Site. Another awe-inspiring architecture built by the King Parakramabahu, The Great since 12th century. Intricate details of carvings of the exterior complex with amazing murals/ wall paintings at the interior of the structure with three massive Buddha statues housed here, hence the given name as Thivanka which literally means three curves. No photo-takings allowed inside the complex in order to protect the murals. Must-visit as part of the sites at Polonnaruwa Ancient Site with entrance fee of USD25. Well worth the penny especially for history buff!

It is located towards the end of tour to Polonnaruwa Archaeological Sites and is one of the important place, which is a must visit. The place had served as a temple to Lord Buddha, having been built in 12th Century. The Temple is in ruined state, however, whatever remains, given an indication of past magnificence. The site is also import, from the point of view of ancient art and has frescoes on the interiors. The whole site is covered by a huge metal roof, to preserve, whatever is left. No photography is allowed inside the temple. The visitor going inside, have to follow a demarcated passage.

Although the murals are worn, they're still worthy of inspection. Overall, one of the better monuments that we saw in either Anuradhapura or Polonnaruwa.
